Please furnish a detailed report for the information of the Hon’ble the Political Resident on the - instructions issued by the Muscat Government prohibiting the reopening of the mission school during Mr. Dykstra’s absence. I For Secretary to the Political Resident, Persian Gulf. * LB 1 . * v'EXTRACT FROM THE MUSCAT INTELLIGENCE SUMMARY NO. 19 FOR THE PERIOD 16th OCTOBER - 31st OCTOBER, 1947. AMERICAN MISSION No. 274* Dr. W.W• Thoms, M.D. of the American ^fedical rfission returned from leave in India on the s.s. Barpeta on the 21st and proceeded on to Basrah in the same ship, together with Mr. D. Dykstra, Missionary of the American Mission. They are attending a Conference at Basrah called by the Mission authorities. During Mr, Dykstra^‘absence the Muscat Government have issued instructions prohibiting the re-opening of the Mission School.-rV 5V Li, D.Q* No* C*/617 ■ 6A Political Agency# Unseat. 8th December 1947. r Please refer to your Hemorandum No. 1960-3 dated the 15th November 1947 on the subject of closing the American Mission School• 2. I understand that the first steps were taken last year when, during the absence of Mr. Pykstra in America on leave, the State Issued a notification prohibiting the opening of Schools and dispensaries without authority from the Government. On his return from America, Mr. Dykstra re-opened his School which consists of about 20 pupils, mainly children of the Mission Hospital workers and assistants. For a short time no question was raised. It then chanced that a mason, a British subject, working in the Mission compound took his son away from the Saidiyeh School and installed him in the Mission School. The headmaster of the Saidiyeh School apparently resented losing his pupil and reported the matter to the Minister of Interior who sent for the mason and demanded to know why he had removed his son from the State School and put him in the Mission School. The mason, apparently a man of independent mind, appears to have told the Minister of the Interior that he was a British subject and would send his son to School v/here he liked, thereupon the Minister of Interior thrust him into gaol, and the Consulate had to intervene and get him out (no report was made to the Consulate at the time that the trouble started over the question of the boy^ schooling). After this incident, the Sultan's Secretary wrote to Mr. Dykstra asking him when, and on what authority, he had opened his School and referred him to the notification pullished last year. Mr. Pykstra replied that he had not been sent a copy of this notification before and that in any case his school was not a newly opened school, that it had been going for many years, and that amongst others who had benefitted by education in the school / was The Hon'ble Sir Rupert Hay, K.C.I.E., C.S.I., Political Resident, Persian Gulf, Bahrain.2 was Mr. Jamali himself. It appears that Mr. Jamali told Mr. Pykstra while regretting the necessity to close the school, Mr. Pykstra would have to conform to the public notification in this respect and obtain the permission of the Government before he opened the school. I understand that the Mission have written to the Sultan about the matter and since they do not wish to create any unnecessary ill will and fuss, have closed the school, pending the Sultan's reply. In the meantime, Mr. Pykstra is setting his pupils home tasks and correcting and advising them as opportunity occurs. Though the notification refers also to the opening of dispensaries, no action has yet been taken against the Mission Hospital or Nurse Mary's Hospital in Muscat. I believe that the Mission are planning to bring out at least two new nurses very shortly and otherwise increase their staff. They are therefore anxious to settle the matter quietly with the Sultan if possible, rather than come to an open clash with the local authorities.* INDIA OFFICE RECORDS Mfcfr 9570 MICROFILM 1

mods.abstract: This file contains correspondence concerning the following:An application made for travel documents and permission to return to Muscat from India by Dr Sarah L Hosman of the American Mission and a nurse named May Edna BarterThe enforced closure of the American Medical Mission school by the Muscat authorities.The correspondence in the file is primarily between officials at the Political Agency in Muscat and the Political Residency in Bahrain.
